__data__.text:
* Tectonic plates interaction in central southern Turkey and northwestern Syria:
	+ African Plate and Arabian Plate boundary represented by the Dead Sea Transform (DST)
	+ Arabian Plate and Anatolian Plate boundary represented by the East Anatolian Fault (EAF)
	+ DST and EAF meet at the Marash Triple Junction
* EAF:
	+ 700 km-long left-lateral strike-slip fault zone
	+ Subdivided into seven segments from northeast: Karlıova, Ilıca, Palu, Pütürge, Erkenek, Pazarcık, and Amanos
	+ Amanos segment also considered part of the DST or a transitional structure between the EAF and DST
	+ Northern strand recognized with 10 segments, from Sürgü to Düziçi–İskenderun
	+ Slip rate decreases south-westwards on the main strand and on the northern strand
* Sürgü-Çardak Fault:
	+ East-west striking 160 km-long fault north of the EAF
	+ Comprising two segments: Sürgü Fault (70 km) and Çardak Fault (90 km)
	+ Seismicity low, only one associated earthquake in 1544
* DST in Turkey and Syria:
	+ Subdivided into seven segments following the 2013 "Active Fault Map of Turkey"
	+ Afrin, Sermada, Armanaz, Hacıpaşa, Yesemek, Sakçagöz, and Narlı segments
* Seismicity:
	+ EAF has produced large or damaging earthquakes in the past few hundred years
	+ Recurrence intervals for M 6.8–7.0 earthquakes on Palu and Pütürge segments, M 7.0–7.4 on Pazarcık and Amanos segments
	+ Research paper in 2002 identified two sections with high potential for future earthquakes, one in Elazığ and Bingöl, which ruptured in 2010

* The Pazarcık and Amanos segments have recurrence intervals of 237-772 years and 414-917 years, respectively, for M 7.0-7.4 earthquakes.
* A study in Earth and Planetary Science Letters in 2002 identified two sections of the East Anatolian Fault with high potential for future earthquakes, including a section in Elazığ and Bingöl, and a 103 km long section in Kahramanmaraş.
* The Elazığ and Bingöl section ruptured during a Mw 6.1 earthquake in 2010, and the Kahramanmaraş section is believed to have last ruptured in 1513, with the potential to produce magnitude 7.3 earthquakes.
* Large earthquakes on the northern part of the DST include events in 115, 526, 587, 1138, 1170, and 1822, resulting in several tens of thousands to several hundreds of thousands of fatalities.
* On February 6, 2023, two earthquakes struck Turkey: a Mww 7.8 earthquake and a Mww 7.5 earthquake.
* The Mww 7.8 earthquake had an epicenter near Gaziantep, a depth of 10.0 km, and a focal mechanism corresponding to strike-slip faulting. It was the strongest Turkish earthquake in over 2,000 years.
* Over 570 aftershocks were recorded within 24 hours of the Mww 7.8 earthquake, and over 30,000 recorded by May 2023.
* A Mww 6.7 aftershock occurred about 11 minutes after the mainshock, and a Mww 6.3 aftershock struck near Uzunbağ in Hatay Province on 20 February.
* The Mw 7.7 earthquake triggered its own aftershock sequence, including two mb 6.0 aftershocks. Aftershocks of the second earthquake continued through at least 9 Feb.

* 25 aftershocks Mw 4.0 or greater within 6 hours of main tremor, USGS
* At least 54 aftershocks of 4.3 or greater magnitude, 12 hours later, USGS
* At least 120 total aftershocks, Turkish Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD)
* Mw 6.3 aftershock near Uzunbağ in Hatay Province on 20 February
* Result of oblique-normal faulting
* Mw 7.8 earthquake had aftershocks along ~350 km (220 mi) of the EAF
* Mw 7.7 earthquake triggered its own aftershock sequence
* Two mb 6.0 aftershocks
* Aftershocks of the second earthquake continued through at least 9 Feb
* Thousands of aftershocks associated with this earthquake
* Distributed along an east-west trend corresponding to the Çardak Fault for about 170 km (110 mi)
* Seismology
* Source model for the Mww 7.8 earthquake produced by the USGS
* Uses three fault segments with individual lengths, widths, strikes and dips of >40 km (25 mi) × 30 km (19 mi), 028°/85° (Segment 1)
* >175 km (109 mi) × 30 km (19 mi), 060°/85° (Segment 2)
* >160 km (99 mi) × 20 km (12 mi), 025°/75° (Segment 3)
* Mainshock produced a maximum slip of 11.2 m (37 ft) along Segment 2
* Another zone of large slip estimated at 4.96 m (16.3 ft) occurred further northeast along Segment 2
* USGS source model for the Mw 7.7 earthquake
* Three large fault segments with individual lengths, widths, strikes and dips of >70 km (43 mi) × >20 km (12 mi), 276°/80° (Segment 1)
*

* The Mw 7.8 earthquake on February 6, 2023, resulted in slip extending to 18 km (11 mi) and 12 km (7.5 mi) for the Mw 7.7 event.
* The Mw 6.4 aftershock in Antakya on February 20 had a rupture area of 25 km (16 mi) x 25 km (16 mi) and produced a peak slip of 0.93 m (3 ft 1 in) at 8.3 km (5.2 mi) depth.
* Preliminary analysis shows up to 3 bars of added stress near the epicenter of the M7.7 shock on the Çardak–Sürgü Fault and 1 bar on the Hatay Fault, which could trigger rupture.
* The initial rupture occurred on the Narlı Fault, the northernmost section of the Dead Sea Transform, and propagated unilaterally northwards until it reached the Pazarcık segment of the East Anatolian Fault.
* The rupture continued bilaterally to the northeast and southwest along this segment, with a total rupture length of ~560 km (350 mi).
* The rupture transitioned to supershear after propagating about 19.5 km (12.1 mi) away from the epicenter along the Narlı Fault.
* The second M>7 earthquake initiated on a separate fault known as the Çardak–Sürgü Fault Zone, part of the northern strand of the East Anatolian Fault.
* The rupture propagated bilaterally along the Çardak segment, continuing eastwards onto the Sürgü segment before continuing eastwards to Malatya along the northeast–southwest trending Doğanşehir Fault Zone.
* The total rupture length was estimated at 160 km (99 mi), with the westward-propagating rupture occurring at supershear velocity and the eastward-propagating rupture occurring at subshear velocity.
* The Mw 6.4 aftershock on 20 February occurred along the Hatay F

* Two earthquakes occurred: a Mw 7.8 and a Mw 7.7
* Total rupture length was 160 km (99 mi)
* Westward-propagating rupture occurred at supershear velocity (max 4.8 km/1.7 mi per second)
* Eastward-propagating rupture occurred at subshear velocity (max 2.8 km/1.1 mi per second)
* Rupture lasted about 35 seconds
* Mw 6.4 aftershock on 20 February along the Hatay Fault with normal faulting
* Surface ruptures mapped using satellite imagery and ground observations
* Two separate zones of surface rupture: 320 km (200 mi) and 150 km (93 mi)
* Remote sensing indicated 30 km (19 mi) of surface rupture with large normal faulting component
* Surface rupture extended from north of Antakya, Hatay Province towards Pazarcık, Kahramanmaraş Province and Gölbaşı, Adıyaman Province
* Maximum displacement of 7.3 m (24 ft) on the surface
* Ground acceleration values recorded in some areas near the fault rupture were in excess of 1 g
* Three USGS seismic installations recorded large ground accelerations and velocities
* Peak ground acceleration of 1.62 g recorded by a station at Fevzipaşa
* Maximum recorded pga was 2.212 g at a station in Pazarcık Belediyesi Parkı, Pazarcık
* Maximum MMI of the mainshock was estimated to have reached MMI XI–XII (Extreme) in Antakya and near the epicenter
* MMI XI (Extreme) or higher was observed along the fault rupture from the epicenter to Antakya
* Maximum MMI of the second earthquake was X (Extreme).

* Earthquakes in Turkey and Syria with maximum MMI of X (Extreme)
* Liquefaction and lateral spreading observed in Antakya, Samandağ, Lake Gölbaşı, İskenderun, and Orontes River plain
* Subsidence, sand ejecta, and flooding in İskenderun
* Tsunami recorded in Mediterranean Sea, Famagusta, Cyprus, İskenderun, and Erdemli
* 50,783 deaths, 297 missing, 107,204 injured in Turkey
* 15.73 million people and 4 million buildings affected in Turkey
* 345,000 apartments destroyed in Turkey
* 2+ million residents evacuated to nearby provinces in Turkey
* 20% of Turkey's agriculture production affected
* 516 university buildings affected, 106 heavily damaged in Turkey
* 1.25 million buildings inspected, 164,000 destroyed or severely damaged in Turkey
* 150,000 commercial infrastructure at least moderately damaged in Turkey
* Over 2.7 million people homeless in Turkey
* 61,722 buildings to be demolished in Turkey, including:
	+ 11,900 in Gaziantep Province
	+ 10,900 in Hatay Province
	+ 10,800 in Kahramanmaraş Province
	+ 28,914 in Malatya Province
* Broad fissures on roads in Turkey
	+ Adana: 12 buildings collapsed, 23 badly damaged, 120 moderately damaged
	+ Malatya: 300 buildings razed, 60% of city's buildings damaged
	+ Out of 968 mosques in Malatya, 25 destroyed, 420 others damaged
	+ Two hotels collapsed in Malatya, causing many casualties

- Adana: 12 buildings collapsed, 23 were badly damaged, and 120 were moderately damaged. 59 buildings and 1,274 apartments were destroyed or required demolition.
- Malatya: At least 300 buildings were razed, 60% of the city's buildings were damaged, and nearly every neighborhood was affected. 25 mosques were destroyed, and 420 others were damaged. Two hotels collapsed, causing many casualties. The airport and historic Yeni Camii mosque were damaged. Damage was reported at the Arslantepe Mound.
- Akçadağ: 11 people died, including four attributed to the second earthquake.
- Doğanşehir: At least 263 deaths were reported.
- Gaziantep: Many historical sites were severely damaged, such as Gaziantep Castle, Şirvani Mosque, and Liberation Mosque. 16,211 collapses and severely damaged buildings were reported. 154 people died in the city center, and 102 died in four other collapsed buildings. In Nizip, at least 51 people were killed when a six-story apartment building collapsed.
- Nurdağı: Nearly 2,500 people died, and about 50% of the houses were badly damaged or destroyed. An additional 30% of its building stock received moderate damage.
- Gaziantep Oğuzeli Airport was forced to restrict its service to rescue flights.
- Sakçagözü: 90% of houses were heavily damaged or destroyed, and 256 people died.
- İslahiye: There were 1,368 deaths, over 1,500 injuries, and more than 200 destroyed apartments.
- Hatay Province: 13,517 buildings collapsed, 8,162 required demolition, and 67,346 were heavily damaged. The districts of Antakya, Kırıkhan, and İskenderun were the most affected.
- Antakya: 70% of homes and 6,369 buildings collapsed, 3,734 had to be demolished, and 21,830 were

- Reyhanlı: 318 buildings collapsed, 1,661 others severely damaged/requiring demolition
- Arsuz: 187 buildings collapsed, 2,176 others badly damaged, 194 others demolished
- Kumlu: 131 buildings destroyed, 738 others severely damaged, 84 others demolished
- Payas: 58 buildings collapsed, 669 others badly damaged or demolished
- İskenderun: large fire at port, 534 buildings collapsed, 3,370 others severely damaged, 4,622 others received severe damage, 3,109 people died, over 12,000 injured
- Erzin District: 31 buildings collapsed, 897 others heavily damaged or demolished, no major damage in largest town
- Samandağ: 670 buildings collapsed, 9,212 others badly damaged or demolished, 7,850 people died
- Hassa District: 1,046 buildings collapsed, 3,452 others severely damaged
- Altınözü: 838 buildings destroyed, 3,892 others badly damaged, 650 others demolished
- Yayladağı: 139 buildings collapsed, 755 others badly damaged, 87 others demolished
- Belen: 11 people died, 107 houses destroyed, 70% of building stock damaged
- Dörtyol: 115 buildings destroyed, 2,030 others severely damaged or demolished
- Kahramanmaraş: mass burials for over 5,000 bodies, 75% of city's buildings damaged or destroyed
- Elbistan: 924 people died, 1,825 injured, 2,000 buildings destroyed
- Ordekdede (Pazarcik District): almost all single-story buildings decimated, 34 people died
- Ekinözü: 11 people died, 107 houses destroyed, 70% of building stock damaged
- Afşin: at least 180 people died, 335 buildings including 90 in

- Four neighborhoods in Adıyaman were destroyed, including Atatürk Boulevard, the city hall, a 6th-century mosque, Gölbaşı District's state hospital, and Isias Hotel.
- Up to 10% of Adıyaman's population perished, and there were also significant damages in Karapınar and Bahçelievler neighborhoods.
- In Gölbaşı, 71% of the town's infrastructure was damaged or destroyed, and 695 people were killed with over 400 injured.
- There were also 410 deaths in Besni District, about 90% of them in the town itself, and at least 55 people died in Kâhta.
- In Diyarbakir Province, 8,086 buildings were damaged, required demolition or were destroyed, including the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Diyarbakır Fortress and Hevsel Gardens.
- Part of the Galeria complex in Yenişehir, which included a shopping mall and dozens of apartments, collapsed, killing 89 and injuring 22.
- In Şanlıurfa Province, at least 466 buildings were heavily damaged, and 201 were destroyed.
- Structures around the Pool of Abraham were damaged, and the minaret at the religious shrine partially collapsed.
- In Osmaniye Province, of the 22,841 buildings surveyed, 1,739 were heavily damaged, destroyed or required urgent demolition.
- In Kilis Province, 119 buildings were destroyed and 138 others were heavily damaged.
- In Batman Province, 218 buildings were damaged, and an additional 15 were completely destroyed.
- In Mardin Province, 59 buildings were heavily damaged and another 190 were slightly damaged.
- In Bingöl Province, several houses cracked and some livestock were killed by collapsing barns.
- In Samsun, damage occurred in Samsun Stadium.
- In Kayseri Province, eight buildings collapsed, while 5,252 others were damaged to some extent.
- Several houses were damaged and a barn collapsed in Muş Province.
- In Sivas

- Three Turkish soldiers died during rescue operations in Syria.
- Over 26 local journalists, 4 doctors, 120 police officers, and 32 gendarmeries were among the dead in Syria.
- At least 8,476 people died and over 14,500 were injured in Syria due to the earthquake.
- 2,153 children and 1,524 women were among the dead.
- The Syrian Ministry of Health recorded over 2,248 earthquake-related deaths and 2,950 injuries in government-held areas.
- At least 4,547 people died and 2,200 others were injured in rebel-held areas.
- 73 medics, 5 media personnel, 62 workers in humanitarian agencies, and 4 civil defense personnel were among the dead.
- An estimated 5.37 million people across Syria may have been made homeless.
- 10.9 million people, nearly half of Syria's population, were affected.
- Over 123 residential areas, villages, towns, and cities were badly damaged.
- Many power plants, water facilities, hospitals, and public infrastructure also sustained damage.
- At least 453 schools were damaged.
- A total of 10,600 buildings had partially or fully collapsed, while thousands of others were damaged in the country.
- Hundreds were killed in the towns of Jindires and Atarib.
- In Jableh, at least 283 people died, 173 were injured, and 19 buildings collapsed.
- Civilians were stuck under the rubble for hours due to the lack of rescue teams in several villages.
- In Latakia Governorate, 142,000 people were affected; at least 805 people died and 1,131 others were injured.
- The Afrin Dam had cracked and burst, flooding the village of Al-Tloul and displacing nearly all its residents.
- Between 35 and 40 people died in Al-Tloul, and most buildings were damaged or destroyed.
- Various archaeological sites in Tartus Governorate were damaged, including the Khawabi Castle and Aleika Castle.
-

- Footballer Nader Joukhadar and his son killed when their home collapsed in Jableh, Syria due to earthquake.
- International Rescue Committee reported earthquake struck when rebel-held areas were preparing for a blizzard and experiencing a cholera outbreak.
- In Aleppo, dozens of buildings collapsed, and at least 444 people died, including 163 children. By 8 February, the bodies of 210 victims were returned to their families.
- Various archaeological sites across the city were extensively cracked or collapsed, including the Aleppo National Museum.
- In Atarib, Aleppo, the Syrian American Medical Society hospital said 120 bodies were recovered.
- About 20,000 homes were affected in Aleppo, leaving 70,000 homeless.
- In Rajo, the doors and walls of a prison facility cracked, and 20 prisoners, believed to be ISIS members, escaped.
- In Damascus, many people fled from their homes onto the streets, and many buildings were cracked.
- Crusader-built castle Margat, Krak des Chevaliers castle, Citadel of Aleppo, Sahyun Castle near Latakia, and the minaret of the Grand Mosque in Kobanî were damaged.
- In Jindires, over 1,100 people were killed and at least 250 buildings were razed.
- At least 6,600 Syrians residing in Turkey were killed, and thousands of Syrians were buried in Turkey due to difficulties transporting them to Syria.
- At least 11 Iraqi war refugees died in Turkey, and most Afghans killed in Turkey were refugees who fled the country after the Taliban takeover in August 2021.
- In Lebanon, residents were awakened from their sleep, and buildings in the country shook for up to 40 seconds.
- In Beirut, residents fled their homes and stayed in streets or drove in their vehicles to flee from buildings.
- The earthquake damaged 16,200 buildings across the country, including 10,460 in Beirut and 4,000 in Tripoli.
- In Ashdod, Israel, a building was evac

- The Department of Fisheries and Marine Research suggested a possible link between beaching and earthquakes due to whales' echolocation system being affected by sea disturbances.
- The earthquake was felt in several countries including Armenia, Egypt, Palestine, Georgia, Greece, Iraq, Jordan, Israel, Russia, Lebanon, and Syria.
- In Iraq, minor damage occurred in Erbil and the city's citadel was severely damaged. In Egypt, tremors were strongly felt in Cairo and a 20m crack appeared in Alexandria's Corniche.
- Aftershocks occurred on 20 February and 27 February, causing further damage and casualties in Turkey and Syria.
- AFAD warned residents to stay away from the coast due to potential tsunami of up to 50 cm.
- In Syria, five people died during stampedes and at least 500 people were injured.
- The USGS PAGER service estimated a 35% probability of economic losses between US$10 billion and US$100 billion, and a 36% probability of deaths between 10,000 and 100,000.
- Risklayer estimated a death toll of between 23,284 and 105,671.
- Övgün Ahmet Ercan, a geophysics professor, estimated that 180,000 people or more may be trapped under the rubble, nearly all of them dead.
- The World Health Organization said up to 26 million people may have been affected; 15 million in Turkey and 11 million in Syria.
- Immediately after the earthquakes, the Turkish lira value struck a record low of 18.85 against the US dollar, but rebounded to its starting position at the end of the day.
- Total cost of earthquake damage in Turkey was estimated by TÜRKONFED at $84.1 billion US dollars; $70.75 billion on rebuilding, $10.4 billion loss in national income, and an additional $2.91 billion loss in workforce.
- Turkish president Recep Tayyip Erdogan said rebuilding would cost $105 billion.
- The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development said

- Turkey's main stock market dropped 1.35% on Feb 6; Borsa Istanbul fell 8.6% on Feb 7, then over 7% on Feb 8, leading to a 5-day closure
- Earthquake damage in Turkey estimated by TÜRKONFED at $84.1 billion: $70.75 billion on rebuilding, $10.4 billion loss in national income, and $2.91 billion loss in workforce
- Turkish president Erdogan estimated rebuilding cost at $105 billion
- European Bank for Reconstruction and Development estimated potential losses may be up to 1% of Turkey's GDP in 2023
- Turkish government preliminary report estimated total damage cost at $103.6 billion, 9% of its GDP in 2023
- About half of residential property in the affected area is covered by Compulsory Earthquake Insurance
- United Nations Development Programme estimated between 116 million and 210 million tons of debris must be cleared in Turkey
- In Syria, World Bank estimated $5.1 billion in damages, excluding economic impact and losses
- Nearly half the cost in Syria was direct damage to residential buildings and 18% on infrastructure
- World Bank estimated reconstruction cost at $7.9 billion, with economy potentially contracting by up to 5.5% in 2023
- Immediate aftermath in Turkey saw thousands trapped under rubble, many people missing, and survivors livestreaming pleas for help on social media
- Officials planned to open hotels in Antalya, Alanya, and Mersin to temporarily accommodate affected population
- Mosques in Turkey used as shelters, people sought refuge in shopping malls, stadiums, community centers, and mosques in Gaziantep
- Nearly 250,000 displaced persons resided in schools across Malatya Province
- Several Turkish humanitarian institutions launched emergency appeals to help victims
- Turkish Airlines provided free flights for volunteers, Pegasus Airlines evacuated 30,771 people, and Turkish Airlines evacuated 139,438 people between Feb 6-11
- Disaster and Emergency Management Authority opened an invitation for citizen volunteers
- President Erdog

* Bilal Ekşi, CEO of Turkish Airlines, stated that 11,780 volunteers were flown on 80 flights to affected areas by Turkish Airlines.
* Pegasus Airlines evacuated 30,771 people from the affected area on 169 flights between 6 and 9 February.
* Turkish Airlines evacuated 139,438 people from the affected area on 790 flights and carried 7,833 members of search and rescue and aid groups to the affected area on 1,595 flights.
* President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan declared a 3-month state of emergency in the 10 affected provinces.
* The national government declared a level four alert to appeal for international aid.
* 25,000 search and rescue personnel were dispatched to the 10 affected provinces.
* At least 70 countries offered to help in search and rescue operations.
* Over 53,000 Turkish emergency workers were deployed to the regions affected from the earthquakes.
* A team of 90 miners from Soma arrived at Osmaniye to provide assistance.
* The Izmir Metropolitan Municipality also sent dozens of vehicles and equipment.
* Poor weather conditions including snow, rain and freezing temperatures disrupted search and rescue efforts.
* Erdoğan visited the town of Pazarcık, Kahramanmaraş Province and Hatay Province on 8 February.
* AFAD announced on 19 February that search and rescue efforts in most of the affected provinces had ceased.
* Kerem Kınık, President of the Turkish Red Crescent, made an appeal on social media urging people to donate blood across the country.
* Many search and rescue teams from various cities and AFAD volunteers reached the affected areas.
* Eight of Turkey's most-watched television channels organized a joint broadcast of an aid campaign, Türkiye Beats with One Heart Campaign on 15 February.
* The campaign received $6.1 billion in donations.
* The Ministry of Youth and Sports, Turkish Football Federation, Super League Clubs Association Foundation and beIN Media Group organized the Omuz Omuza campaign which raised $44.8 million on the first day.
*

* On February 15, the Türkiye Beats with One Heart Campaign was organized by eight channels and featured on 213 television channels and 562 radio stations, receiving $6.1 billion in donations.
* The Central Bank of the Republic of Turkey was the largest donor, pledging $1.6 billion, followed by Ziraat Bank and VakıfBank, each pledging $1 billion.
* The Omuz Omuza campaign, organized by the government, raised $44.8 million on the first day.
* The government promised to pay compensation to those who have lost their homes and provide relocation assistance per household to those whose homes were moderately, heavily, or totally destroyed.
* Rent assistance of up to ₺5,000 would be given to homeowners and ₺2,000 to tenants.
* President Erdoğan promised to rebuild destroyed homes of survivors within one year and provide temporary accommodation for those made homeless.
* Force Majeure was imposed in the affected region, and tax obligations between 6 February and 31 July 2023 were postponed until 31 July 2023.
* Over 1.9 million people were rehoused in dormitories, guest houses, tents, hotels, and containers.
* 387,000 tents had been established in the affected area by local and international organizations.
* 890,000 survivors were placed in dormitories, and 50,000 in hotels.
* 162 container cities were established across the affected region.
* The Turkish government announced plans to construct 200,000 homes in the 11 affected provinces and a further 70,000 in villages.
* On February 7, Turkey accused the People's Defense Units of having overseen an MRL attack on its border checkpoint, and the Turkish army responded with further attacks.
* The Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) declared a ceasefire in its conflict with Turkey.
* On February 9, three inmates were killed and 12 more injured after soldiers opened fire during a prison riot in Hatay.
* On February 11, German and Austrian

* Prisoners demand to see families affected by earthquake
* German and Austrian rescuers suspend operations in Hatay due to worsening security situation, later resume with Turkish Land Forces protection
* Israeli search-and-rescue group United Hatzalah leaves Turkey due to "concrete and immediate threat"
* Syrian family of seven killed in house fire in Nurdağı, Turkey
* Natural gas explosion in Şanlıurfa kills two, injures five, damages businesses
* Bus collision on Tarsus-Adana-Gaziantep Motorway kills two and injures six
* IF1 tornado strikes camp housing earthquake survivors in Pazarcık, Kahramanmaraş, killing three and injuring 50
* Floods in Adıyaman and Şanlıurfa kill at least 14, sweep away cars, affect homes and campsites
* Floods in Adıyaman result in two drowning deaths
* Over a dozen professional divers participate in search and rescue efforts in each province
* Elections planned for 14 May 2023, but doubts arise if they can be held on schedule due to earthquake
* AKP authorities state elections will not be delayed
* CHP, İYİ party, and HDP oppose postponement on constitutional grounds
* Earthquake leads to postponement of anti-Erdoğan coalition's meeting for selection of consensus presidential candidate
* Erdoğan-lead electoral People's Alliance retains majority in Grand National Assembly
* Erdoğan receives 49.5% in first round and 52.2% in second round of presidential election
* Education suspended at universities in affected provinces, student hostels used to house affected individuals
* All schools in country closed for two weeks, schools in affected provinces suspended until 10 March
* Students studying in schools located in affected provinces transferred to other provinces of their choice
* Süper Lig suspended for over a week to mourn earthquake victims.

* First Turkish presidential election run-off
* Council of Higher Education suspended university education and training in affected provinces
* Student hostels managed by General Directorate of Higher Education Credit and Hostels to house affected individuals
* Minister of National Education, Mahmut Özer, ordered a week-long closure of all schools, later extended to two weeks
* Schools in affected provinces suspended until 10 March, students studying in affected provinces transferred to other provinces
* Süper Lig suspended for over a week to mourn earthquake victims
* Süper Lig clubs Hatayspor, Gaziantep FK, TFF First League club Yeni Malatyaspor, Adanaspor, TFF Second League club Adıyaman FK, Diyarbekirspor and TFF Third League clubs Kahramanmaraşspor, Osmaniyespor FK and Malatya Arguvan SK withdrew from competition
* 2023 ISF World School Winter Games in Erzurum canceled due to 'force majeure' situation
* 2023 Men's EuroHockey Indoor Club Cup in Alanya canceled due to earthquake impact
* Every national championship suspended until further notice
* 39 members of Northern Cypriot Türk Maarif Koleji's high school volleyball team died in Adıyaman hotel collapse
* Three players from Iran's national paralympic football team died in Turkey
* Hatayspor's Ghanaian winger Christian Atsu died in Rönesans Rezidans collapse in Antakya
* Basketball player Nilay Aydogan died in Malatya
* Fenerbahce Istanbul and Konyaspor fans protested Turkish government, called for resignation
* Besiktas and Antalyaspor fans repeated calls for government's resignation, threw cuddly toys onto the field
* President Bashar al-Assad held emergency meeting, organized rescue plan for affected regions
* Civil defense, firefighting, health, and public construction groups mobilized to affected governates
* Medical services, food, and shelter urgently needed
* Ministry of Internal Trade and Consumer Protection tasked with supplying food and organizing distribution teams
* Ministry of Water Resources tasked with assessing damage to dams,

- Syria requested aid from the European Union's European Civil Protection Mechanism.
- Syrian government wants to distribute aid in all areas, including rebel-held territories.
- UK and US plan to deliver aid through their respective humanitarian partners.
- Damaged roads and logistical issues prevent international aid mobilization from Turkey.
- Border crossings into Turkey remained closed on 7 February, but Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing was accessible on 8 February.
- Critically injured patients unable to enter Turkey for medical attention, exceptions made for individuals with touristic residence permits.
- Hotels, refugees, expatriates, and universities offer shelter to survivors.
- High number of casualties and trauma cases overwhelm hospitals, causing overcrowding and shortage of medical supplies.
- Ministry of Health dispatches medical convoys and aid to Aleppo and Latakia.
- Local charities, like Saed Initiative and al-Bir and al-Ihsan, distribute meals and plan to establish charity kitchens.
- Over 2,000 Syria Civil Defense (White Helmets) volunteers conduct search and rescue efforts.
- Officials announce end of rescue and recovery efforts in Hama after 15 hours.
- Over 298,000 people left without homes, 180 shelters opened in government-held areas, and about 30,000 people housed in shelters in Aleppo.
- No international rescue workers had arrived in rebel-held Jinderis despite official calls for help as of 10 February.
- US sanctions against Syria hinder humanitarian efforts; Syrian Arab Red Crescent urges Western countries to lift sanctions.
- Sanctions include oil embargo and freezing of financial assets of the state and government officials.
- US exempts sanctions against Syria for 180 days for earthquake relief efforts on 10 February.
- International humanitarian assistance enters northwestern Syria on 9 February via Turkey through the Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing.
- Turkey works to open two additional border crossings.

* On 10 February, the US announced 180-day sanctions exemption for Syria for earthquake relief efforts
* Syrian Ministry called the decision "misleading" and "false"
* International humanitarian assistance began entering Syria on 9 February via Turkey through Bab al-Hawa Border Crossing
* US Central Command to cooperate with Syrian Democratic Forces to assist affected population in Syria
* WHO director-general visited Aleppo on 11 February with a shipment of emergency medical supplies
* Schools across Syria, except for those in affected areas, resumed on 12 February
* Syrian government agreed to open border crossings at Bab al-Salam and al Raée for three months on 14 February
* President al-Assad met UN relief chief Martin Griffiths on 21 March to discuss post-earthquake recovery and aid
* Arab League secretary-general called for international assistance for those affected by the earthquake
* ASEAN expressed solidarity and readiness to extend assistance to the relief efforts
* European Union's European Civil Protection Mechanism was activated, and 31 rescue teams and 5 medical teams were dispatched to Turkey
* EU committed €3 million and €3.5 million to Turkey and Syria respectively, and announced a donor conference to raise money
* NATO secretary-general said that member countries were mobilizing support
* NATO deployed "fully equipped semi-permanent shelter facilities" to house displaced persons in Turkey
* UN announced coordinated responses to the disaster, including UNDAC, OCHA, UNHCR, UNICEF and IOM
* The World Health Organization's Regional Director for Europe said the organization's regional offices were assisting international efforts to transport medicine and relief equipment
* The UN released $25 million from its emergency fund for humanitarian assistance in Turkey and Syria
* A second $25 million grant was released for relief efforts in Syria
* The World Bank said it would provide US$1.78 billion in aid for Turkey to support the relief and recovery process
* Turkish Government criticized on social media for allegedly trying to cover up the fact that there were not two, but three mainshocks above Mw 7
* Additional allegations were made when the death toll in Turkey was at 41,000, could in fact be up

* World Bank preparing rapid assessment of needs after earthquakes in Turkey
* Social media criticism of Turkish government for allegedly covering up facts about earthquakes
* Professor Hasan Sözbilir states two mainshocks above Mw 7, but one smaller quake reached Mw 6.7
* Accusations of manipulated death toll, initially at 41,000 but potentially up to five times higher
* Quality of concrete and engineering design in newer high-rise buildings contribute to collapse
* Building codes last updated in 2018, but complaints of poor enforcement
* Erdoğan claims 98% of destroyed buildings were built before 1999, but civil engineer Haluk Sucuoğlu disputes this
* Comparison of satellite images shows destruction in newly built areas, contradicting Erdoğan's claim
* Protests in Adıyaman against minister of transport and infrastructure and governor
* Critics say contractors allowed to skip safety mandates, putting residents at risk
* Videos show Erdoğan applauding housing projects that later collapsed
* Before 2018 general election, 3.1 million buildings granted amnesty certificates
* In ten affected provinces, 294,165 certificates were granted
* After 2018, US$2 billion generated in profit from illegal construction in İzmir
* Opposition leader Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu pins responsibility for disaster on Erdoğan, demands CHP mayors to continue aid efforts.

- In 2020, a destructive earthquake hit İzmir, Turkey, causing massive damage.
- The Turkish government profited $2 billion from a zoning amnesty law approved in May 2018, with 811,000 certificates linked to illegal construction in İzmir.
- Opposition leader Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu of the CHP accused President Erdoğan of responsibility for the disaster's scale and urged CHP mayors to provide aid despite bureaucratic obstacles.
- There were allegations of relief organization donations being relabeled as government assistance and misuse of the "earthquake tax" from the 1999 earthquake.
- Kurdish and Alevi residents claimed discrimination and neglect in the government's recovery efforts, with pro-Kurdish HDP accusing authorities of unequal aid distribution.
- Disaster and Emergency Management Presidency (AFAD) was criticized for slowness during the first days of the earthquake, centralization, and lack of autonomy.
- AFAD's board of management was questioned due to some members' lack of disaster management background, including the general manager, İsmail Palakoğlu.
- The military's late deployment and aid control by local governors were criticized, with reports of political placards and signs being forced on aid packages and trucks.
- A state of emergency was approved in 10 provinces, but the opposition voted against it, claiming it was unnecessary and that aid was slow and limited.
- Residents in Samandağ, Hatay Province, dug through rubble for victims due to the slow government response, with assistance arriving 48 hours after the earthquake.
- NetBlocks reported limited access to Twitter in Turkey, with government officials citing disinformation as the reason. The block was criticized for hindering aid organization and information sharing.

Note: The summary is written in bullet points as requested, with a length of 261 words.

- Opposition voted no to a measure, claiming it was unnecessary as provinces were already declared disaster areas.
- Residents in Samandağ, Hatay Province, dug through rubble for victims due to slow government response.
- Media reports that ICTA limited access to Twitter in Turkey, with government officials claiming disinformation.
- Block caused public anger as Twitter assisted in sharing information on arriving aid and survivor whereabouts.
- Peoples' Democratic Party criticized the block, stating it would cause more death.
- Ali Babacan, leader of Turkey's opposition group, Democracy and Progress Party, also criticized the block.
- Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) issued a statement critical of fines and penalties on Halk TV, Tele1, and Fox by the Radio and Television Supreme Council.
- Turkish police detained four people over "provocative posts" on social media following the earthquake, with a wider investigation ongoing.
- Authorities arrested 98 people for robbery or defrauding victims following reports of looting.
- Syrians faced increased discrimination, with some blaming them for looting, and allegations of torture by Turkish security forces.
- Minister of justice, Bekir Bozdağ, announced a judicial investigation into the collapse of buildings and identified 131 individuals linked to the collapse.
- By 25 February, 612 people were investigated, 184 were arrested, and 31 arrests were made in Adana and Malatya.
- Committee to Protect Journalists (CPJ) published an article on journalists being detained and harassed for their reporting on the earthquake.
- Owner of the collapsed Renaissance Residence was arrested in Istanbul, and two people were arrested in Gaziantep for cutting-down columns.
- Bekir Bozdağ stated 163 people were being investigated for their alleged involvement, with eight arrested and awaiting trial.

- Some individuals were investigated and arrested for "spreading misinformation" or "provoking people into animosity and hatred" in relation to their reporting on the earthquake in Turkey.
- The owner of the collapsed Renaissance Residence in Hatay Province was arrested in Istanbul while trying to leave Turkey for Montenegro.
- Two people were arrested in Gaziantep Province for cutting down columns in a building that collapsed.
- 163 people were being investigated for their alleged involvement in the collapse of buildings.
- Eight people were arrested and awaiting trial, 48 were held in police detention, seven were prohibited from leaving Turkey, and two were detained at Istanbul Airport attempting to flee to Georgia.
- A man and his wife who constructed several buildings in Adiyaman that collapsed were among those arrested.
- A contractor involved in developing the Bahar Apartments in Gaziantep was detained in Istanbul after inspections were deemed negligent.
- The owner of a construction company which built several buildings in Adana was apprehended in Northern Cyprus.
- The majority of buildings that collapsed were constructed before 2000, but some were constructed after that year.
- Corruption is high in Turkey's construction sector, leading to abuses.
- Seven days of national mourning was declared in Turkey, Northern Cyprus, Bangladesh, and Kosovo, and one day in Albania.
- Syrian government and opposition criticized the lack of humanitarian aid in opposition-held territories, particularly in the Idlib region, which was the worst-struck area in the earthquake.
- The US Treasury and United Nations have been criticized for their policies regarding humanitarian aid in Syria.
- Ankara and the Turkish-backed Free Syrian Army were accused of blocking aid convoys sent by the Autonomous Administration of North and East Syria from entering the north-west region.
- The United Nations criticized Russia's attempts to block delivery of aid through checkpoints to rebel-held territories.
- The United Nations urged the Security Council to immediately permit aid flows into Northwestern Syria.
- The United States appealed for the immediate opening of all closed checkpoints to send in relief efforts to all parts of Syria.
- The United Nations confirmed that some aid is getting into the north-west, but the

- António Guterres urged the Security Council to immediately permit aid flows into Northwestern Syria.
- US appealed for the immediate opening of all closed checkpoints to send in relief efforts to all parts of Syria.
- An emergency UN Security Council meeting was called to increase humanitarian assistance through Bab al-Hawa and open up more border crossings for the entry of UN aid.
- Some aid is getting into the north-west through the Bab Al-Hawa crossing, but the UN does not possess heavy equipment or search and rescue teams.
- Raed al-Saleh, chief of Syrian Civil Defence, rebuked the UN for its negligence and delay in responding to the rescue efforts.
- Below-freezing temperatures in the affected areas in both Turkey and Syria pose a risk of hypothermia.
- Concerns have arisen regarding the possible spread of infection in areas where sanitation facilities are damaged or unfunctional.
- Water shortage experienced in both countries increases the risk of waterborne diseases and outbreaks of communicable diseases.
- On 18 February, Turkey's Health Minister Fahrettin Koca said there was an increase in intestinal and upper respiratory infection cases but "numbers did not pose a serious threat to public health."
- A clinic managed by 15 to 30 medics attended up to 10,000 patients in a day at a stadium serving as shelter in Kahramanmaraş.
- Many people at the stadium were unable to shower and the six toilets were unable to accommodate to the large number of people.
- Health authorities in Turkey had to ensure earthquake survivors were free of disease.
- The World Health Organization collaborated with local authorities to monitor the rates of waterborne diseases, seasonal influenza and COVID-19 among the affected.
